summary: Having survived the first part of their unsettling journey, Bilbo Baggins (Martin Freeman) and his companions (Ian McKellen, Richard Armitage) continue east. More dangers await them, including the skin-changer Beorn and the giant spiders of Milkwood. After escaping capture by the dangerous Wood Elves, Bilbo and the dwarves journey to Lake-town and, finally, to the Lonely Mountain, where they face the greatest danger of all: the fearsome dragon Smaug (Benedict Cumberbatch).

My favorite part of the Hobbit trilogy! The love triangle between Kili, Tauriel, and Legolas was a weird addition that wasn't remotely necessary, but I liked all of the other changes from the book. I especially appreciated the fleshing out of Bard's character, I think this movie does a great job of representing his character. I also really enjoyed the part with Smaug, I thought Benedict Cumberbatch did a great job of being this terrifying beast and Martin Freeman is great as Bilbo as well.
Like the first Hobbit movie, this one is just ok. Sadly, the most interesting part comes at the very end. It needed way more Smaug and way less everything else.

It's not surprising that I didn't like this one quite as much. It's the second one and it has to fill that gap between us meeting all the characters to the big finale. We even saw this in The Two Towers. However, this one really doesn't do it. Martin Freeman is great again, Lee Pace gives such a menacingly ethereal performance, the dwarfs kept that great chemistry that they had in the last movie (even though there's even less focus on them than the first movie), and Luke Evans is a phenomenal Bard. And that's *furiously flips through notes* all the positives I've got. The additions of Tauriel and Legolas and the love triangle between the two of them and Kili (it's less of a love triangle and more of a love line with one point looking on longingly). Oh, and you know how it feels really tacked on and out of place? That's because it was a reshoot addition that was done behind those three actors' backs. So...there's that. The CGI and action is really hit or miss (that final fight with Smaug in the cave defies any remote laws of physics). Also, if you ever have even the slightest desire to watch the extended editions, just don't. They add absolutely nothing of value and anytime I saw something that was added in, I just thought "why the hickety heck was this filmed in the first place?"

The voice of Cumberbatch as Smaug is perfectly fitting and for the first time in all the LOTRs and Hobbit films, there is no sight of Gollum. The cliffhanger ending is also perfectly poised for a fitting final film

It's a solid sequel, but the first one was much more enjoyable.

Thanks to the incredible acting of our three protagonists, as well as the wonderful coldness of Lee Pace and the diabolical genius of Benedict Cumberbatch, this film shines where many others would fail.  Yes, there were changes made from the books (Legolas, Tauriel, etc.), but they service the story rather than existing merely for the purpose of fanservice.  Legolas and Tauriel play roles in the story, and the romance with Kili does not feel as inorganic as many claim (Tauriel was already on the verge of leaving Mirkwood to help the outside world.  That is what drives her, not her feelings for Kili, which only develop at the end of the third film).  Epic action?  Check.  Great acting?  Check.  Fantastic script, camerawork, and sets?  Check.  This movie has it all.

An improvement to the previous installment, "The Desolation of Smaug" continues the trend of terribly overdone CGI and a story that is stretched out too far, though it is done with much more charm, and the new plot points introduced actually make sense, being a welcome addition to the story. The action sequences are much better, and the addition of Smaug is menacing and thrilling to watch. On the topic of Smaug, Cumberbatch does phenomenal in this film as both Smaug and the Necromancer, though his role as Smaug is definitely his highlight in this film. The story is still fine and doesn't feel as stretched out or convoluted as the previous installment. The CGI still looks awful, however. Overall, a much better film than "An Unexpected Journey," and the cliffhanger at the end leaves its viewers eager to see the conclusion of this trilogy.

87/100. With a quicker and in my opinion, better pace than the first movie, it feels like ‘The Desolation of Smaug' is a non-stop action/adventure movie. Thorin, Bilbo, and Gandalf continue to have great character development throughout this movie and the return of Legolas from the original trilogy adds a great callback. Finally, the effects and use of Smaug in this movie is something that surprised me with how well it was done. As soon as Bilbo enters the mountain and encounters Smaug, the movie did a great job of setting the tone and suspense to the point where viewers could feel the tension. If you are a fan of the original Lord of the Rings movies as well as ‘The Hobbit' books, ‘The Desolation of Smaug' is a must see.

I don't even know where to begin with why this doesn't work. It's entertaining enough, but it's not true to the book, there's and over reliance on CGI, the pacing is all over the place, and the cliffhanger ending is kind of pointless since it's resolved in the first fifteen minutes of the following film. This movie is a mess.

THE DESOLATION OF SMAUG will never  make sense without the Unexpected Journey and the Battle of the Five Armies. It picks up in the middle of something and ends in the middle of something and all the characters go through the middle of something throughout the movie. 
This doesn't make it bad by any means but it makes it difficult to be anyone's favorite to watch on its own on a rainy afternoon. 
What it does  have is Legolas, Kate from Lost, Ronan the Accuser, Dr. Strange and Trevor Beaumont. And a massive red dragon with a superb monster design.
Woah! That was unexpected. THE HOBBIT: THE DESOLATION OF SMAUG is an intense ride that will leave you wanting more, with top notch action sequences, amazing graphics, and wonderful storytelling.

An improvement over the first movie. It's much better paced with barely any boring moments, better choreographed action sequences especially the barrel sequences, it was cool seeing the ring having an influence on Bilbo and he once again has many great moments, Benedict Cumberbatch was an amazing Smaug (and that CGI is remarkable) and the scenes with him and Bilbo were so suspenseful, we got to see brand new locations in this movie, Tauriel was pretty awesome and once again, it absorbs you into the story of Middle Earth with great character moments and the stakes and suspense are higher and you feel that throughout the movie, this time for the actual world as we see Sauron's forces gathering and Suaron himself. Not to mention it's visually stunning. It's not perfect though. The romance with Tauriel and Killi is so forced and just weird (an elf and a dwarf?), it was annoying that we did not get to see much Gandalf and it's really convenient that Tauriel and Legolas arrived at LakeTown at the perfect time. Most of the dwarves are still forgettable The weakest part is the cliffhanger and it's not an Empire Strikes Back or Infinity War cliffhanger where it still felt like a complete story. It's not a satisfying ending and not a complete ending but it's still a great movie overall and definitely an improvement over the first.

The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug, is an improvement from an Unexpected Journey but only by a smidge. While an Unexpected Journey suffered from a slow pace, that had an uneven tone, this movie thrives off of the faster pacing, and better mixing of tone. The only downgrade is the script which does go down in quality in favor of the faster pacing and more thrilling sequences. As a sequel it does its job exceptionally well, building up characters, and raising the stakes. Only if this movie had a sharper script, I think this could have been an amazing watch. So 7/10, an improvement that surprised me.

This movie is the perfect example of why the 'Hobbit' series is too long.  Bilbo's journey is kind of set off to the side to make room for Middle Earth politics and for Legolas and Tauriel to each shoot about 50 orcs in the eye while doing backflips.  It is a great movie and visually impressive, don't get me wrong, but there are some stretches that strain credulity even in Middle Earth.  Probably the low point for Jackson's Tolkien films.
While it has great action and scenery, this film felt like it dragged on and later became uninteresting so I instead thought of the shrimp tacos I ate earlier.

Still very good, but I found 'The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug' to be a step below the preceding 2012 release.

The conclusion is what affects it the most, in my opinion. It isn't anything bad, but it goes on for too long - yet the ending itself comes out of nowhere a little. It's iffily crafted, with the entertainment value not enough to cover it up. Again, nothing anywhere near terrible... just not as great as I wanted/expected.

I also kinda wanted more scenes with Martin Freeman (Bilbo) across the midway point. I like the focus on Richard Armitage (Thorin) & Co. but I felt there needed to be more with the lead - and with Ian McKellen (Gandalf), for that matter.

I've led with my negatives first, but I have many positives too. I enjoyed the scenes in Esgaroth with Luke Evans (Bard), all of the stuff there looks awesome. The character of Tauriel, played by Evangeline Lilly, is cool. Orlando Bloom (Legolas) remains fun to watch. Everything else, including the score, is very nicely done - as anticipated.

Love the end credits song ("I See Fire") by Ed Sheeran, by the way. Not quite as grand and great as "May It Be" from LOTR, but it's pretty close!
Benedict Cumberbatch makes a menacing Smaug and I really enjoy the cliffhanger unlike most people.

The Desolation of Smaug held a steady and confident path forward, drumming up even more excitement with its ending. The cast was strong to the finish, and it really was beautiful, with every department using talented force. Although, I do have to say that the elf-dwarf love triangle was really awful. But, that can be easily forgotten with the thrills of Smaug the Magnificent, the Necromancer, and Azog and his formidable orcs.

I wouldn't call The Hobbit: The Desolation Of Smaug a bad movie. It does have a great score, beautiful production design, some neat new characters, a mostly good visual look, decent effects, an interesting dwarf-elf relationship, and every scene with Smaug was perfection. However the characters don't go through enough development or interesting dilemmas, it can visually look ugly or distracting at times, and a good portion of the special effects don't hold up anymore.

Rating: C-

The adventure continues and brings a more epic nature to “The Hobbit” franchise. Add a beautifully designed CGI dragon and Elves and it starts to feel like Middle Earth again. The highlight of this film is the final act involving Smaug The Dragon. He is a cunning and almost perfect CGI Antagonist who shapes the film in a new direction. Sadly the film takes a few detours to showcase new characters, both liked and also some completely useless. The biggest problem with the film is there is too many new characters and not enough for them to do. This leaves some of the plot pointless yet entertaining at the same time.

I like this movie, but it's a step down from the first movie. There are a lot of parts that I really like, but there are also a lot of parts that I found to be somewhat boring. The action is pretty awesome aside from occasional goofiness within action scenes. I also like the score although we don't get a continuation of their awesome theme from the first movie. The Lake Town stuff is little odd and the Smaug scenes are really boring. Also, the dwarf-elf love story I could do without. Even with the things that I don't like, this movie is still likeable to me.

83%. 7/15/22:  Similar strengths as the first one. Love the elf city in the forest. Love the city on the lake they go to. Just not as action-packed as the first. A lot of lead-up with Smaug. Felt like a build up for the final Hobbit movie

An action-packed and adventurous middle chapter of this prequel series, combined with Jackson's direction, the script he co-wrote with Walsh, Boyens and Del Toro, the performances of the cast, Shore's score, Lesnie's cinematography, Olssen's editing, Hennah's production design, Vincent and Bright's set decoration, Taylor, Maskrey and Buck's costume design, action sequences, sound design and visual effects, The Desolation Of Smaug sets up a confident, action-packed and visually stunning conclusion to this prequel series!!!
Not as good as the first of The Hobbit trilogy, and stretched to be too long, but it is still an entertaining movie.

Extended Edition - A serious entry that again builds upon the world of middle earth and introduces us to new and favorite characters from the past. I enjoyed this quest as much as I did the first installment. The first installment had charm and heart, this had more urgency and was a spectacle to behold. The characters are more fleshed out and you still root for them by the time the credits roll. Problem - again, it’s the problematic CGI - hazy and unfocused. But I’m unfairly comparing it to TLOTR series where they had actual props. The CGI isn’t noticeably off because whenever there is any, the scenes are fast moving, quick... which is another problem that I had, the disorienting camera work. I’m opposed with forced characters thrown in just for laughs. What I mean to say is that I hated the unibrow character - couldn’t they attempted to make the personality on the same lines as wormtongue. Instead we get this tongue-in-cheek character that’s as poorly introduced as the cosmetics they put on his face. Favorite scene - the river scene
